Title: "Neural connections of the posteromedial cortex in the macaque."
Abstract: "The posterior cingulate and the medial parietal cortices constitute an ensemble known as the posteromedial cortex (PMC), which consists of Brodmann areas 23, 29, 30, 31, and 7m. To understand the neural relationship of the PMC with the rest of the brain, we injected its component areas with four different anterograde and retrograde tracers in the cynomolgus monkey and found that all PMC areas are interconnected with each other and with the anterior cingulate, the mid-dorsolateral prefrontal, the lateral parietal cortices, and area TPO, as well as the thalamus, where projections from some of the PMC areas traverse in an uninterrupted bar-like manner, the dorsum of this structure from the posteriormost nuclei to its rostralmost tip. All PMC regions also receive projections from the claustrum and the basal forebrain and project to the caudate, the basis pontis, and the zona incerta. Moreover, the posterior cingulate areas are interconnected with the parahippocampal regions, whereas the medial parietal cortex projects only sparsely to the presubiculum. Although local interconnections and shared remote connections of all PMC components suggest a functional relationship among them, the distinct connections of each area with different neural structures suggests that distinct functional modules may be operating within the PMC. Our study provides a large-scale map of the PMC connections with the rest of the brain, which may serve as a useful tool for future studies of this cortical region and may contribute to elucidating its intriguing pattern of activity seen in recent functional imaging studies."

@BrainMaps_Delineation.Comments: The actual article does not reveal the delineation of the area. Furthermore there are no pictures of the results, so it is not clear if the mentioned delineation is made in the same experiment or earlier.

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "Frontal lobe: Terminal labeling was seen in the most polar part of the prefrontal cortex in area 10. Interestingly, this created a column of terminals perpendicular to the pial surface in the most dorsal part of this cortex toward the midline in the dorsomedial frontal polar cortex i.e., 10 dm. Terminal labeling could be detected in the very first coronal section of the frontal lobe. On the dorsolateral surface of the prefrontal cortex, area 46d on the dorsal aspect of the principal sulcus, received projections in its infragranular region. However, in several sections posteriorly, a relatively higher density of axonal terminal was seen in the ventral bank of the principal sulcus in area 46v. Area 9 and area 9/46 also received similar projections, which continued in the same density and pattern until they disappeared where area 8 was reached.  Cingulate gyrus. Area 32 contained columnar terminal labeling. More posteriorly, area 24a and b also received columns of projections. These columns were juxtaposed to each other. Further posteriorly, at the coronal level of the anterior striatum, the terminal labeling created three distinct columns occupying areas 24 a, b, and c. By comparison, area 23c, only in its anterior regions, contained a relatively lower density of labeling, which was not columnar but localized in the deep layers. Different levels of area 31 received axonal terminals in different forms, i.e., either localized in the infra and supragranular layers or as a column covering all of the layers. We found terminal labeling in columns and layered in the supragranular area 23b and 23a contralaterally.  Parietal lobe. Projections targeted area 7m and the lateral area PG although the terminal labeling in the PG was of much lower density and only in the sections coincident with the injection site. In both of these areas, the projections were columnar.  Temporal lobe. Projections targeted the entorhinal cortex (EC) in relatively lower densities compared to area TPO, which received a higher density of terminals in its infragranular layers. Of note, the terminals into the TPO spanned from the anterior TPO to its more posterior regions with few interruptions. Only a low density of projections was seen in the infragranular layer of the STA.  Subcortical Efferents. Basal ganglia: The putamen contained only a few patches of terminal labeling. We could not find projections to the contralateral putamen. The caudate nucleus, however, had a much higher density of labeling in a bar manner that extended from the anterior regions of the head to the most posterior regions of the body of the caudate nucleus. The density of terminal labeling in the head of caudate nucleus was by comparison much higher than the density of terminal labeling in the more posterior sections of this nucleus. Terminal labeling in the nucleus accumbens was mainly ipsilateral, but a much lower density of labeling could also be seen contralaterally.  Thalamus. A continuous bar of terminal labeling was seen in the dorsolateral domain of the thalamus. The terminal labeling was seen in the anterior nuclei AV, AM, and continued posteriorly in the LD. A much less denser labeling was seen in the most dorsolateral tip of the VL and VA before gaining more strength again in the LP and pulvinar regions. We also observed relatively lower density of terminal labeling in two separate patches within the anterior and medial pulvinar.  Brainstem. We found terminal labeling in the dorsolateral periaqueductal gray matter. The projections entered the periaqueductal territory from its dorsomedial aspect and gave rise to a concentrated patch of axons and boutons in its dorsolateral column. These axonal terminals could be seen in an »4,500-mm rostrocaudal stretch of the dorsolateral PAG. The other brainstem structure that received projections from area 23a and b was the pontine gray, i.e., the nucleus of the basis pontis (BP). Labeled neurons in the BP were clustered in two patches, one centered in the caudal ventromedial and the other in the rostral ventrolateral region of this pontine structure and the longest patch extended for »400 mm rostrocaudally.  Others. Zona incerta contained a relatively high density of patches of terminal labeling."

"We found terminal labeling in columns and layered in the supragranular area 23b and 23a contralaterally. [...] Terminal labeling in the nucleus accumbens was mainly ipsilateral, but a much lower density of labeling could also be seen contralaterally."

"A2. Case M3-BDA-29/30/(23a): Cortical Efferents. Frontal lobe: Buried in the ventral aspect of the principal sulcus, columnar terminal labeling was seen in area 46v. The cortex on the dorsal bank of the sulcus was void of any terminal labeling. Areas 9 and 9/46 also received projections in its infragranular layers.  Cingulate gyrus: A bilayered pattern of terminal labeling was seen in area 32 in its superficial and deep layers. Scattered but a very high-density columnar labeling was seen along the rostrocaudal axis of the anterior cingulate area 24a. In area 23, the density of terminal labeling seemed to increase, and a larger number of dense terminal columns could be seen in area 23a and 23b. In area 31, columns of terminal labeling targeted its anterior domains, whereas more posteriorly, a relatively lower density of labeling was seen in the infragranular layers. Areas 29 and 30 were also targeted by very dense columnar fibers. Homotopical labeling was also seen as columns targeting the contralateral areas 29 and 30 and less densely the area 23a.  Parietal lobe. Supragranular and infragranular layers of area PG contained a bilayered pattern of terminal labeling. Only a lesser density of scattered axonal terminals were seen in area 7m.  Temporal lobe. Labeling was seen in the EC either as columns or only in its deep layers. A comparatively lower labeling was found in the superficial layers of the para- and presubicular areas. TPO was targeted in a patchy manner, i.e., whereas the anterior TPO contained superficial terminal labeling, the more posterior parts had infragranular labeling. Area TF received a much less impressive projections scattered in several layers.  Subcortical Efferents. Striatum. The most dorsal domain of the head of caudate nucleus contained a dense labeling of axonal terminal. This labeling continued ipsilaterally in a bar manner, in the same domain of the nucleus, until the end of the body of the caudate nucleus was reached. Terminal labeling in the head of the caudate nucleus was bilateral and located in the same dorsal domain of the nucleus. The contralateral terminal labeling was scattered and noncontinuous. The nucleus accumbens received ipsilateral projections from the injected cingulate area, but compared to the labeling seen in the caudate nucleus, the density of accumbens labeling was much less.  Thalamus: As shown in Fig. 3, an intense labeling was seen in the nucleus AV and AM. On adjacent sections, the AM contained axonal terminals. Interestingly, some of the labeled projecting axons cross the midline and target the AM on the contralateral side of the thalamus (Fig. 3 a and a'''). At this level, also, the nucleus reuniens (Re) contained terminal labeling bilaterally. The labeling in the thalamus continued topographically in the lateral and dorsal domain of the thalamus in a bar pattern spanning across the nuclei LD, VL, LP, and anterior and lateral pulvinar. The BDA labeling in the dorsal VL complex was localized in its most dorsolateral tip. Overall, the terminal labeling in the thalamus was so dense that a dark patch of labeled axons could be seen on the mounted slices with a naked eye.  Brainstem. Only the dorsolateral column of the PAG contained terminal labeling. In the basis pontis, two distinct patches of terminal labeling were located in the ventral and ventromedial territories of this nucleus. These extended for »150 mm.  Others. Zona incerta and pregeniculate areas contained few labeled axonal terminals. "

"Homotopical labeling was also seen as columns targeting the contralateral areas 29 and 30 and less densely the area 23a. [...] Terminal labeling in the head of the caudate nucleus was bilateral and located in the same dorsal domain of the nucleus. The contralateral terminal labeling was scattered and noncontinuous. [...] Interestingly, some of the labeled projecting axons cross the midline and target the AM on the contralateral side of the thalamus (Fig. 3 a and a'''). At this level, also, the nucleus reuniens (Re) contained terminal labeling bilaterally.

"A4. Case M4-BDA-7m: Cortical Efferents. Frontal lobe: Terminal labeling was found on the dorsal bank of the principal sulcus in area 46d. A relatively higher density of labeling was also seen on the lateral surface of the brain on the dorsal bank of the same sulcus in area 9/46. These continued posteriorly and became more segregated and patchy in the dorsal and medial aspects of the brain in areas 9d, 9m, 8b, and 8ad. These projections were all concentrated in the supragranular cortices. Only few scattered axonal terminals could be seen in the superficial mesial area 6, but we could not trace these projections in consecutive sections.  Cingulate gyrus. No terminal labeling was seen in areas 32, 24a, or 24b, but an intense terminal labeling could be seen in area 24c in the superficial layers of the anterior segment of this cortex. Only one patch of columnar terminal labeling was seen in area 23c, but this labeling had faded away in the next slices. More posteriorly, area 31 received columnar terminal labeling in all its layers. Areas 23a and b or 29 and 30 did not receive afferents in this case.  Parietal cortex. Lateral PG and area PE had terminal labeling in several cortical layers. The contralateral area 7m had a high density of columnar labeling.  Temporal lobe. Only the very posterior region of the TPO had a columnar terminal labeling. Superficial layers of the presubiculum were targeted by axonal terminals.  Subcortical Efferents. Striatum. The dorsolateral head of the caudate nucleus was again seen to contain terminal labeling. This labeling continued in a bar-like pattern to the end of the body of the nucleus in the same dorsolateral domain. Scattered patches of labeling were also seen on the contralateral side in the same domain of the nucleus. Compared to other experiments mentioned above, a higher density of terminal labeling was seen in the dorsolateral putamen.  Thalamus: Terminal labeling in the thalamus was centered on the dorsolateral domain of the LP. Compared to other experiments mentioned above, a higher density of labeling was scattered in three patches within the lateral pulvinar. No terminal labeling was seen in the anterior or the other nuclei of the thalamus.  Brainstem. The basis pontis contained one single patch of terminal labeling in its dorsomedial region. This patch extended in a column for »2,000 mm.  Other. Terminal labeling in the zona incerta was present and similar to the ones observed in case M3-FR-31. In the claustrum, a few patches of relatively low-density terminal labeling could be found in the ventral and anterior regions of this structure."

"The contralateral area 7m had a high density of columnar labeling. [...] The dorsolateral head of the caudate nucleus was again seen to contain terminal labeling. This labeling continued in a bar-like pattern to the end of the body of the nucleus in the same dorsolateral domain. Scattered patches of labeling were also seen on the contralateral side in the same domain of the nucleus.

@Methods_Animals.Comments: Animals are described as young adult

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "A3. Case M3-FR-31: Cortical Efferents. Frontal lobe: Area 10d contained terminal labeling both in the supra- and infragranular layers. Further posteriorly, both on the dorsal and ventral banks of the principal sulcus, areas 46d and 46v, respectively, had a columnar terminal labeling. Other areas of the prefrontal cortex receiving projections were area 9, 9/46, and 8b. The terminals labeling in these areas were mostly in the supragranular layers.  Cingulate gyrus. Area 32 contained patches of terminal labeling in its deep layers. Although, areas 24a or 24b did not show any terminal labeling, area 24c had a columnar terminal labeling that was seen in a patchy form in the most anterior region of 24c and in the transitional zone between areas 24c and 23c. In the posterior cingulate gyrus, columnar terminal labeling was seen in anterior 23b and anterior 23c as well as 31. Close to the injection site itself, homotopical terminals were found on the opposite hemisphere covering all of the cortical layers of area 31. Retrosplenial areas 29 and 30 were void of terminal labeling.  Parietal lobe. Area 7m contained terminal labeling that was at times bilayered (superficial and deep layers) and at times columnar. Otherwise, lateral PG and area PE received terminals in their supragranular layers.  Temporal lobe. We found superficial and deep layer terminals in the presubiculum. These were continuous for »2,500 mm in the anterior segment of this cortex and were absent in the posterior sections. Only the middle segment of the TPO had terminal labeling in its supragranular layers. The entorhinal cortex or other temporal lobe regions were void of any labeled terminal labeling in this experiment.  Subcortical Efferents. Striatum: Only a few small patches of axonal terminals were seen in the core of putamen. Compared to density of terminals in the putamen, the dorsolateral domain of the head of caudate nucleus contained a relatively much higher density of terminal labeling. The FR-labeled terminals in the caudate nucleus continued uninterruptedly in a bar manner until they reached the end of the body of the nucleus. Parallel to these terminals were the BDA labeled axonal terminals on the contralateral caudate nucleus. The BDA labeled projections were originated from the contralateral 29/30/23a, which was injected in the same monkey, M3.  Thalamus: We found a strikingly similar pattern of terminal labeling in the thalamus (Fig. 3). FR-labeled terminals were seen on one side and BDA terminals on the other side, mirroring each other in the same nuclei of the thalamus. We called this finding the "parallel bar" pattern because the BDA and FR terminals resembled two parallel bars on the dorsum of the thalamus extending from the anterior-most tip to the posterior-most tip of the thalamus. The difference was that FR-labeled axons (i.e., projections originated in area 31) were missing in the nucleus reuniens (Re) and in the contralateral nucleus of AM but were relatively more abundant in the pulvinar than in the anterior nuclei. Overall, the FR labeling was much less intense in the anterior nuclei compared to the BDA labeled ones originated from 29/30/(23a). The FR-labeled terminals targeted the dorsolateral tip of the VA complex and continued posteriorly in the LD and the dorsalateral VL. In more posterior sections, there was terminal labeling in the LP and a relatively higher density of labeling in the anterior pulvinar. This labeling continued to dominate the dorsal region of the anterior pulvinar in consecutive sections. No terminal labeling was found in the inferior or medial pulvinar.  Brainstem. The basis pontis received two patches of ipsilateral terminal labeling in its most ventral part. Otherwise, we found no projections to the PAG or other brainstem regions in this case.  Other. Among the other structures, only the zona incerta received terminal projections. In the claustrum, a patch of relatively low-density terminal labeling was found in the ventral and anterior region of this structure."
"Close to the injection site itself, homotopical terminals were found on the opposite hemisphere covering all of the cortical layers of area 31.

"R3. Case M1-FB-31 (Fig. 9): Cortical Afferents. Frontal lobe: In the very anterior sections of the frontal lobe, a column of labeled neurons was seen in the dorsal aspect of area 10d. This labeling continued more posteriorly in the infragranular layers of area 9 and then more densely in the same layers of area 8B. Another line of labeling was seen in area 46 within the dorsal bank of the principal sulcus (area 46d) in a bilayered pattern in both infra and supra granular layers. Labeled neurons were seen in separate columns within the depth of this sulcus in a junctional area between 46v and 46d.  Cingulate gyrus. In the most anterior sections, only few labeled neurons were seen in area 32, 24a, and 24b, whereas a relatively much more numerous neurons were labeled in area 24c. Labeling in the anterior cingulate gyrus was seen in its different layers in separate sections. Area 23c had a high density of labeling in its anterior territories. This area corresponds to Morecraft and Van Hoesen’s cingulate M3 motor region (presumably the hand and arm area) (11). Areas 23a and 23b had a relatively much higher density of labeling in a columnar manner. Area 31 was covered with a relatively very high density of labeled neurons both anterior and posterior to the injection site. This labeling, although in lesser density, was also seen on the homotopical region of the other hemisphere.  Parietal lobe. Area 7m was covered with a very high density of labeled neurons both anterior and posterior to the injection site. Although this labeling involved many layers of 7m, we could discern distinct columns of labeling. Areas PEa, located in the dorsal bank of the intraparietal sulcus, and area POaE on the other bank of the same sulcus had columns of labeling. Area PG contained labeled neurons scattered in entire territory rather than in distinguishable columns.  Temporal lobe: Several layers of the most posterior region of the TPO had strong labeling, whereas the anterior or mid segments of this cortex were void of any labeling. In the EC, labeling was confined to deep layers whereas the subicular cortices had labeling in more superficial layers.  Subcortical Afferents. Claustrum: From the very anterior sections of the claustrum to the posterior boundaries of this structure, a high density of labeling appeared in its entire mantle. A vertical panel of cells covered the claustrum on every single coronal section in which this structure was present. The more ventral domain of the claustrum had the highest density of labeling.  Thalamus: Compared to other cases, the thalamus had a very high density of labeled neurons in anterior nuclei AV, AM, but not AD. Labeling was also seen in the intralaminar nuclei central medial, PC, and superior CL. More posteriorly, the dorsal domain of the thalamus had labeling of cells in the VL, LP, and the anterior pulvinar. In the MD nucleus of the thalamus, labeling was not only seen in the MDdc as in other cases, but also in the lateral parvocellular segment of the MD (MDpc). Furthermore, labeling was observed in the entire posterior nuclear complex. The lateral and medial pulvinar displayed a large number of labeled cells. The overall pattern of labeling seen in this case is different from any other case in that it incorporates many more nuclei and in much higher density.  Basal forebrain. Labeling was seen in the vertical limb of the diagonal band of Broca."

"Area 31 was covered with a relatively very high density of labeled neurons both anterior and posterior to the injection site. This labeling, although in lesser density, was also seen on the homotopical region of the other hemisphere.

"R1. Case M2-FB-23b/a (Fig. 7): Cortical Afferents. Frontal lobe. Labeled cells were located in area 10 starting from the very first section of the frontal lobe anteriorly in the infragranular layers of the medial area 10 (10m) and continuing posteriorly, keeping their location in the deep layers. More impressive labeling was seen in area 46. This labeling was exclusively on the dorsal bank of the principal sulcus and with a very high density. Area 9 contained a relatively lower density of labeled neurons on its most dorsal territory, closer to the cortical vertex. Some labeling was also seen in the transitional area between area 9 and 46d on the edge of the lateral cortex overlying the principal sulcus. These neurons were scattered in supragranular, granular, and infragranular layers.  Cingulate gyrus: In the most anterior sections of the cingulate gyrus, there was a high density of labeling in the infragranular layers of area 32 that presented itself as one single cluster rather than a continuous band. Marching posteriorly, labeled neurons appeared in superficial layers of area 24a. Labeling in both area 32 and 24a continued in a patchy and noncontinuous manner posteriorly and also involved area 24b. The density of labeling increased suddenly as we approached the level of the anterior commissure, where labeled cells were located at the core of area 24'b, a transitional area between areas 24 and 23 (10). Further posteriorly, a relatively lower density of labeled neurons appeared in areas 29, 30, 23a, and 23b until a very high density of neurons appeared in areas 23a and 23b and 29 and 30 immediately anterior and posterior to the injection site (Fig. 7I). On the same coronal level, we found scattered labeling in the contralateral areas 23a and 23b that had a much higher density closer to the injection site and became more scattered further away from the coronal level of injection site.  Parietal lobe. Few labeled neurons were seen in the supragranualr layers of area 7m. Otherwise in a few posterior sections, labeled neurons were seen in the same layers of area PG close to the tip of the intraparietal sulcus.  Temporal lobe. Area TPO had no labeling in its most anterior sections. However, in its middle and posterior territories, labeled neurons were abundant. Depending on the section, some labeling was concentrated in the granular, whereas in other sections an infragranular or columnar labeling was the pattern of labeling. Area STA contained labeling in its infragranular layers. We found labeling in the superficial layers of the EC. These formed a cluster of labeled neurons in a few consecutive sections in the most posterior regions of the EC.  Subcortical Afferent. Thalamus. In the anterior thalamus, labeling was noted in the nuclei AV and AM. Intralaminar nuclei CL, PC, and midline CM nucleus also contained labeled neurons. The labeling in the anterior nuclei was near the border with the internal medullary lamina, thus making the labeling in the rostral intralaminar nuclei and the anterior nuclei noninterrupted. Anterior nuclear labeling was restricted to AV in more caudal sections, and labeling in the intralaminar nuclei continued through most of the anteroposterior extent of the thalamus including the superior CL nucleus, which courses above MD, and medial to the LD nucleus in more caudal regions. The nuclei LD, LP, and caudal segments of lateral MD (MDdc) also contained labeled neurons. Labeled cells in these nuclei were more dispersed than the labeling in the anterior complex. In posterior sections, labeling was present in the posterior nuclear complex, including an intense labeling in nucleus limitans and the LP forming a strip of labeled cells along the thalamo-mesecephalic junction. The anterior pulvinar also contained labeled neurons, although extremely posterior segments of the pulvinar had no labeling. Overall, the density of the labeling varied along the anteroposterior axis of the thalamus.  Claustrum. Labeled cells were mostly concentrated in the ventral region of this structure and continued all of the way in an uninterrupted manner until the most posterior region of this structure.  Basal forebrain. A low density of labeled neurons was present in the medial septal area and the vertical limb of the diagonal band of Broca.  Subcortical Afferents. Thalamus. The labeled neurons in the thalamus were seen in the dorsal segment of VL and continued with greater density into the LP and the anterior pulvinar, forming an area of labeled cells occupying the posterior and dorsal part of the thalamus. Only a few cells were labeled in the MDdc.  Claustrum. Labeled neurons appeared on the very anterior slides of this structure, and the density of labeled cells increased in the middle region of the claustrum and continued in high density to the last sections of this structure. In the most posterior sections of the claustrum where the relative volume of this structure had diminished, the density of labeled neurons gradually disappeared. Labeled neurons in the anterior claustrum were concentrated in the ventral region of this structure, but also a lesser density of labeling was seen in more dorsal domains of the structure. The labeled neurons in the ventral domain of the claustrum were at the same horizontal level as the opening of the lateral fissure. The ventral labeling continued in an uninterrupted manner into the posterior slides.  Basal forebrain. Labeled neurons were seen only in three slides. The labeled neurons corresponded to the large cells of the substantia innominata."

" On the same coronal level, we found scattered labeling in the contralateral areas 23a and 23b that had a much higher density closer to the injection site and became more scattered further away from the coronal level of injection site."

"R2. Case M3-FB-30/23a (Fig. 8): Cortical Afferents. Frontal lobe: Labeled neurons were located both in the dorsolateral and orbitofrontal prefrontal cortices. Two lines of labeling were seen in the dorsolateral region: one line begins in the infragranular layers of area 10, including 10md, 10d, and 10 dl and continued posteriorly in area 9md and in relatively lesser density in area 8 dl before ending in the dorsal bank of the superior arcuate sulcus in area 8B. The second line begins in the ventral bank of the principal sulcus in 46v in a relatively very high density in a bilayered format, i.e., both supragranular and infragranualr layers, continuing posteriorly to area 9/46v and involving the dorsal bank of the principal sulcus in area 9/46d in its infragranular layers. In the orbitofrontal cortex, neuronal labeling started in the deep layers of area 11 and continued to areas 13 and 25 in the same deep layers.  Cingulate gyrus. Labeled neurons were seen in the deep layers of areas 24a and 24b. Few cells were also seen in the superficial area 32, but we were not sure whether these neurons were in the most anterior tip of area 24 or in area 32 itself. Therefore, in Table 2, we mark this terminal labeling as (+). In the posterior cingulate gyrus, areas 23a and 23b, contained labeled neurons in either subgranular or supragranular and, at times, granular layers. Area 31 had labeled neurons in a columnar manner. Areas 29 and 30 also contained a relatively much stronger density of labeled neurons in both hemispheres. On the contralateral side, we could see scattered neurons in area 23a, but the majority of contralateral homotopical labeling was in areas 29 and 30.  Parietal lobe. The infragranular layers, and in sections close to the intraparietal sulcus also the supragranular layers, of area PG contained only a few labeled neurons. Only very few neurons, if any, were labeled in areas PO.  Temporal lobe. The labeling in the TPO was either scattered in the supragranular, infragranular, or in all its layers. The labeling was present mostly in the posterior regions of the TPO. We found labeling in the EC and presubicular/subicular regions in both superficial and deep layers. Labeled cells were also found in the basolateral nucleus of the amygdala (»5–10 labeled neurons on each slice) spanning for almost 1,500–2,000 mm. Also of note, labeled cells were present in area TF. These cells were noncontinuous and clustered. More anterior or posterior sections of the TF were void of labeled cells.  Others . We found labeling in the prostriate visual cortices.  Subcortical Afferents. Thalamus. As shown in Fig. 5, labeling appeared in the AV and AM nuclei of the thalamus ipsilaterally. Of note, the same thalamic territory on the other side received anterograde terminals labeled with BDA in case M3-BDA29/30(23a). Next, a relatively low density in AV and a higher density of labeling in the AM were seen. Interestingly, retrograde-labeled cells continue toward the midline in the AM nucleus of the thalamus but stop at the midline seam. There were no retrogradely labeled cells on the contralateral IM nucleus. More posteriorly, labeled neurons diminished in density as the anterior thalamic nuclei diminish in size. A relatively lower density of labeled neurons was seen in the central medial nucleus, one of the anterior intralaminar nuclei (aILN). Toward the ventricular space, in the LD nucleus, the retrogradely labeled cells were of higher density and continued in the same territory toward the LP nucleus and the dorsal domain of the anterior pulvinar. Patches of neurons were also seen in the posterior sections of the pulvinar and the parafascicular and nucleus centrum medianum (CnM) of the posterior intralaminar nuclei (pILN).  Claustrum. Labeled cells were mostly concentrated in the ventral claustrum and spanned from the most anterior to the most posterior sections of the structure in an uninterrupted manner. In the more anterior regions of the claustrum, we could see labeled neurons extending into the more dorsal regions of the claustrum but in a lesser density. More posteriorly, this form changed to a patch of labeling in the ventral region.  Basal forebrain. Few labeled neurons were seen in the medial septal and the vertical limb of the diagonal band of Broca."
"On the contralateral side, we could see scattered neurons in area 23a, but the majority of contralateral homotopical labeling was in areas 29 and 30.

"R4. Case M5-FB-7m (Fig. 10): Cortical Afferents. Frontal lobe. In the first sections of the frontal lobe, no labeled cells could be seen in the frontal polar cortex of area 10. However, we observed the first labeled cells in area 9 in low densities (2–3 labeled cells per slide). Once area 9/46 was reached, the density of labeled neurons continued to be low. Labeled cells were located area 9/46 and 46d in the infragranular layers and could be seen on each consecutive section while they kept the same location on the dorsal bank of the principal sulcus. More posteriorly, area 8AD contained labeled cells in similar layers below the superior arcuate sulcus. We could notice an increase in the density of labeled neurons once the cytoarchitecture changed from 9/46 to 8. Further posteriorly, labeled cells were seen in the medial area 6m, which Paxinos defines in rhesus monkey as area 6/32 (12).  Cingulate gyrus. Labeled neurons were seen in the ventral bank of the cingulate sulcus in area 24c. These neurons were in the granular and infragranular layers and in the anterior region of this cingulate cortex. They were absent in more posterior sections of the anterior cingulate cortex. In area 23c, the labeled neurons appeared suddenly in a high density (»40 neurons per slides) involving all layers of this cortex. However, in some sections, the labeling was segregated in a bilayer pattern involving the supra and infragranular layers. Labeled neurons were seen in area 31 and 23b and a few if any in area 23a, but when they appeared, they involved several layers of the cortex giving the labeling a columnar pattern.  Parietal lobe. In area PG, labeled neurons were located in the opercular region i.e., on the dorsal bank of the lateral fissure, and involved the deep layers, whereas in the PE, the neurons were lesser dense and located in either the most dorsal tip of this cortex closer to the vertex (i.e., area PEc) or in cortex buried into the intraparietal sulcus (i.e., area PEa). These neurons were mostly located in the deep layers. Closer to the injection site, a high density of neurons were seen in area 7m on both hemispheres.  Temporal lobe. Only one region was found to be the source of projecting neurons to area 7m. These neurons were clustered together in a high density in the deep layers of the TPO buried in the dorsal bank of the superior temporal sulcus.  Subcortical Afferents. Thalamus. The labeled neurons in the thalamus were seen in the dorsal segment of VL and continued with greater density into the LP and the anterior pulvinar, forming an area of labeled cells occupying the posterior and dorsal part of the thalamus. Only a few cells were labeled in the MDdc.  Claustrum. Labeled neurons appeared on the very anterior slides of this structure, and the density of labeled cells increased in the middle region of the claustrum and continued in high density to the last sections of this structure. In the most posterior sections of the claustrum where the relative volume of this structure had diminished, the density of labeled neurons gradually disappeared. Labeled neurons in the anterior claustrum were concentrated in the ventral region of this structure, but also a lesser density of labeling was seen in more dorsal domains of the structure. The labeled neurons in the ventral domain of the claustrum were at the same horizontal level as the opening of the lateral fissure. The ventral labeling continued in an uninterrupted manner into the posterior slides.  Basal forebrain. Labeled neurons were seen only in three slides. The labeled neurons corresponded to the large cells of the horizontal limb of the diagonal band of Broca/substantia innominata."
"Closer to the injection site, a high density of neurons were seen in area 7m on both hemispheres."

publication.title: "Neural connections of the posteromedial cortex in the macaque."
publication.abstract: "The posterior cingulate and the medial parietal cortices constitute an ensemble known as the posteromedial cortex (PMC), which consists of Brodmann areas 23, 29, 30, 31, and 7m. To understand the neural relationship of the PMC with the rest of the brain, we injected its component areas with four different anterograde and retrograde tracers in the cynomolgus monkey and found that all PMC areas are interconnected with each other and with the anterior cingulate, the mid-dorsolateral prefrontal, the lateral parietal cortices, and area TPO, as well as the thalamus, where projections from some of the PMC areas traverse in an uninterrupted bar-like manner, the dorsum of this structure from the posteriormost nuclei to its rostralmost tip. All PMC regions also receive projections from the claustrum and the basal forebrain and project to the caudate, the basis pontis, and the zona incerta. Moreover, the posterior cingulate areas are interconnected with the parahippocampal regions, whereas the medial parietal cortex projects only sparsely to the presubiculum. Although local interconnections and shared remote connections of all PMC components suggest a functional relationship among them, the distinct connections of each area with different neural structures suggests that distinct functional modules may be operating within the PMC. Our study provides a large-scale map of the PMC connections with the rest of the brain, which may serve as a useful tool for future studies of this cortical region and may contribute to elucidating its intriguing pattern of activity seen in recent functional imaging studies."
